courses.description: The United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for 2015-30 30 were adopted to strive for a world that is ‘just, equitable and inclusive’. Those priority risk behaviours causing global burden of diseases are often established early in life and research findings have also confirmed the existence of common determinants (e.g., pathways in the brain) and the inter-relationships between the determinants of risk behaviours and behaviours themselves.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For TPg student in 
- Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health; - MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics; - MSc/PgD in Health Services Management; - MSc/PgD in Health Promotion and Behavioural Health programme.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topic
Intro to Health & Social Behavior Concepts/Course Overview
[Before class, please watch the 11 mins video from US CDC “REACH: Improving Lives, Inspiring Hope”
(
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6s6nhK4o_gU&list=PLvrp9iOILTQaklFMK28M7_0mju-qXnjjV&index=29
)
Tutorial 1: Quick review of basic concepts & overview of the Group Project
(please download
Group Project Proposal Form)
Theoretical Basis of Social & Behavioural Health Interventions I:
(Health Belief Model and
Theory of Reasoned Action/Planned Behavior
)
Open period for projects discussion among group members
Theoretical Basis of Social & Behavioural Health Interventions II:
(Social Cognitive Theory/Stages of Change/Social Support)
Open period for projects discussion among group members
Behavioural Health Interventions III: (Diffusion of Innovations)
& Review of health behaviour theories
Free discussion time at end of review session to decide on target population & health behaviour intervention for group project
Health Promotion Needs Assessment & Objective Setting in the Planning phase of Health Promotion Programme Development
Health Promotion Programme Implementation & Process Evaluations with case study from Social Marketing
Health Promotion Project Implementation: Role of Government
Tutorial 2: Tutorial with project discussion of proper objective setting using S.M.A.R.T. (Submit Group Project Proposal Form to tutor at end of the tutorial session)
Midterm (covering lectures 1-6): MCQ & Essay format
Open group discussion session
(Final approval of project topics given w/ comments by head tutor)
Health Promotion Project Implementation: Community Advocacy (Case study of Global Tobacco Control and Anti-smoking policies)
Tutorial 3: Programme Implementation Tutorial with project discussion
Health Promotion Programme Implementation: Healthy Settings Approach
Tutorial 4: Programme Implementation (part 2):
5 minutes presentation by each group on Project (limited to 4 slides) at end of tutorial session for feedback by tutors and classmates: Targeted population and health behaviour, rationale for project + primary outcome of interest+ main methods of intervention+ setting
Health Promotion Programme Monitoring & Evaluations
Tutorial 5: Monitoring and outcomes for project tutorial
Examples of health promotion in real life (online component)
Grass-roots school health promotion: UNICEF India: Teaching children how to improve health, hygiene, and sanitation (
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHV6WC-TEwY
)
Discrimination & health promotion in resource poor communities: “China: Fighting HIV/AIDS” (
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-lW2V-6beAk
) .
Challenges of health promotion programmes facing political and religious opposition: “Pakistan conflict threatens polio campaign” (
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aV2F__PSyxk
)
Please choose one of the above videos to do the 1 page brief exercise –download from Blackboard
Open discussion session for students to meet for project discussion
Tutorial 6: Group Project discussion with tutors and professors
Turn in brief HW exercise from last week’s video
Final 20 minutes group presentation + 10 min Q & A session
(Protocol due 2 weeks later by 11:59 PM)
courses.required_readings:
Glanz, K., Rimer, B.K., and Viswanath, K. 2008.
Health Behavior and Health Education: Theory, Research and Practice
(4
th
Edition). Jossey-Bass.
Nutbeam, D., Harris, E., and Wise, M. 2010.
Theory in a nutshell: a guide to health promotion theory
. (3
rd
Edition) McGraw-Hill Book Company Australia.
Glanz, K. and Rimer, B.K.. 2005
.
Theory at a Glance: A Guide for Health Promotion Practice. US Natl Cancer Institute. http://www.sbccimplementationkits.org/demandrmnch/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Theory-at-a-Glance-A-Guide-For-Health-Promotion-Practice.pdf

courses.subject: HPSB
courses.title: Health Promotion Programme Planning and Implementation
courses.description: This much needed course is designed to provide a practical course in the planning, needs assessment and development of health education and health promotion programmes.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For TPg student in
- Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health; - MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics; - MSc/PgD in Health Services Management; - MSc/PgD in Health Promotion and Behavioural Health programme.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to
- Detail and apply the intervention mapping framework for the developing health promotion programmes
- To come up with concrete, logistically-feasible, theory-based health interventions
- Understand the components of health program planning and implementation
courses.course_syllabus:
Health Promotion Planning: Two Perspectives
Needs Assessment: What do they feel missing?
Segmentation: Who is the priority segment?
Exchange: What do they want in return?
Positioning: What is unique about our offer?
Marketing mix: How to deliver our offer?
Health Promotion Programme Management
courses.required_readings:
Kotler P, Lee NR. Social marketing: influencing behaviors for good. 4
th
edition. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage. 2011.

courses.subject: HPSB
courses.title: Health Promotion Programme Evaluation and Monitoring
courses.description: This course is designed to provide a practical course in the monitoring and evaluation of health promotion programmes. It describes the various methods of evaluation and the latest advances in this field.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For TPg student in: 
- Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health; - MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics; - MSc/PgD in Health Services Management; - MSc/PgD in Health Promotion and Behavioural Health programme.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Student should be able to
- Detail and apply the intervention mapping framework for the developing health promotion programmes
- To come up with concrete, logistically-feasible, theory-based health interventions
- Understand the components of health program planning and implementation
courses.course_syllabus:
An overview of program evaluation
Evaluation designs
Formative and process evaluation
Outcome evaluation
Impact evaluation
Analysis and interpretation of program evaluation data
Program Evaluation Case Study
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
McKenzie, J, Neiger, B, Smeltzer, J. (2013) Planning, implementing and evaluating health promotion programs: A primer. 6
th
Edition. Pearson Education, Inc.

courses.subject: HPSB
courses.title: Healthy Settings
courses.description: The United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for 2015-30 30 were adopted to strive for a world that is ‘just, equitable and inclusive’. Those priority risk behaviours causing global burden of diseases are often established early in life and research findings have also confirmed the existence of common determinants (e.g., pathways in the brain) and the inter-relationships between the determinants of risk behaviours and behaviours themselves. Improvement of behaviours and well-being of citizens would not naturally occur without a specific “intentional intervention”. The concept of Healthy Setting is to cultivate a healthy physical/psycho-social environment in the setting where people spend most of the time for working, studying, enjoyment of life, or for specific purposes. It is a very effective “intentional intervention” in achieving improvements in both health and well-being of citizens as it would penetrate into the wide arrays of their daily experiences. The whole concept of healthy setting is also based on striving the principles of ‘just, equitable and inclusive’ for citizen development. The key to successful implementation is engagement of key stakeholders in strategic way.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For TPg students under School of Public Health
courses.learning_outcomes: After completion of this module, student should be able to acquire the basic knowledge and skills in applying the concepts of Healthy Settings to improve health of their target population on different health issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
Discussion: Promoting health using the setting approach and the roles of different settings
Participants will be designated a short question and will provide a brief answer in class.
* student should watch the pre-recorded lectures before joining the class on 26 Jun on overview of Healthy Setting approach.
The concept of the Healthy Cities Project and analysis of city health
Case examples of Health Promoting School and analysis of school health profile
New paradigm of primary health care to promote better health in community: District Health System
Health Promoting Workplace: Introduction
Health Promoting workplace: Assessment , monitoring and evaluation for good human resource management
Health Promoting Health Care settings: Case presentation and discussion
Briefing for mini-studies
Tutorials for mini-studies
Mini-studies
Student Presentation
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
Lee A., Lo ASC, Li Q., Keung MW, Kwong CM.
Health Promoting School: An Update
. J Applied Health Economics and Health Policy
2020;
https://doi.org/10.1007/s40258-020-00575-8
Nam EW
,
Lee A, Moon JY, Yea Li-A Song YL, Dhakal S. Analyze the characteristics of the healthy cities projects using HP-Source.net in Korea.
International Journal of Health Promotion and Education
, 2015; DOI: 10.1080/14635240.2015.1010655
Lee A.
Evaluation of Healthy Cities in Korea: SPIRIT Check List Analysis Results. Korean Healthy City Forum
. Organsied by Korean Healthy City Partnership and Allaince for Healthy Cities. Gangdong-Gu, Korea, 25-26 September, 2019.
Lee A., Lo ASC, Keung MW, Kwong CM, Wong KK. Effective Health Promoting School for better health of children and adolescents: Indicators for success.
BMC Public Health
2019;
19:1088
https://doi.org/10.1186/s12889-019-7425-6
WHO.
Healthy cities: effective approach to a rapidly changing
. Geneva: WHO, 2020
Lee A.
Synergistic Effect of Joining Up Different Healthy Settings to Improve Population Health.
Key speech for the session with full paper: The settings approach moves toward the future. The 3rd Global Conference of the Alliance for Healthy Cities. Ichikawa, Japan 24-26 October 2008.

courses.subject: HPSB
courses.title: Health Communications
courses.description: This course aims to integrate health promotion with the creation and development of health messages. The Course will cover the theories related to interpersonal and public health communications, principles and techniques for designing and disseminating effective health messages, plus class activities facilitating applications of the knowledge in real-life health settings.(pre-requisite: HSPB5001 or HSOC5001)
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For TPg students under School of Public Health:
- Master of Public Health / Postgraduate Diploma in Public Health;- MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics;- MSc/PgD in Health Services Management.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
of the course
Brief overview on Health Communication
Interpersonal Health Communication
(In-class exercise)
Public Health Communication
(In-class exercise)
Health Literacy
(In-class exercise)
Exam (1.5 hours)
Discussion of Group Project (1.5 hours)
Planning and Development of Health Communication Strategies
(In-class exercise)
Use of media in health communication
(In-class exercise)
Group Project Presentation
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teacher.
courses.recommended_readings:
Schiavo, R. (2014).
Health Communication: From Theory to Practice.
San Francisco, CA: Jossey-Bass.
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. (2004).
Making Health Communication Programs Work.
Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Retrieved from
http://www.cancer.gov/publications/health-communication/pink-book.pdf
